comment_body: @marian-pritsak could you also help check if there are other places need such changes?
@stcheng , this is the PR [#796 ](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/796). Looks like there were some changes that got merged when this PR was in review and was not rebased.
@prsunny yes i noticed this. i wonder there might be some other tests/features get broken due to this change.
@stcheng , sure will check with Marian on any other missing cases. Please merge this once the VS test pass.
the passing rate for vnet_bitmap is still low

> retest this please
It is already tested before I submit this PR. What further information is required?
@RichardWu-Hebut there're new fixes merged after the previous check.

~~I see one benefit of original code. If the time used in doTask is not trivially short, it will schedule the next timer after everything done. It has no risk to schedule more frequent than what could be handled.~~
If you see that as a solid benefit, we should for one shot timer, instead of periodic one. That way upon firing, you complete the task and start the next timer run.
@renukamanavalan , can you add more descriptions in the pr?
what if the interval changed, how to you reset the timer interval?

1) When CRMOrch starts, it starts a periodic timer for a default interval of 5 mins and saves it in m_pollinginterval.
2) Whenever polling interval changes, it calls CrmOrch::handleSetCommand, which sets the new interval and restarts timer.
3) Whenever timer firing is sensed (through epoll), the CRMOrch::doTask(timer &) is called.

CRMOrch stops & starts the time in each call to doTask. No other Orch client that uses SelectableTimer does that.

Fix: Remove the redundant restart.

If it is intended that we restart the timer upon each firing, then we should not go for periodic timer, and instead call one shot timer. Upon getting called, do the task and start the next one shot timer.
BTW, this is not a fix for any issue/bug. I just happened to notice, while analyzing SelectableTimer::readData failure.
Nope! By theory, it should not.
We requested some similar change in watermarkorch https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/781

I would recommend switching to producerstatetabe view comparison mechanism as that being used in teamsyncd. It helps to reduce the maintenance effort, also producerstatetabe view comparison mechanism is more flexible.
@jipanyang can you point me to an example? I need to get the problem under control first. Can we move on then improve?

@jipanyang I found the code you are talking about. This code is not generic, it is written for team management only. There needs to have some refactoring and abstracting before it can be generally in other cases. Right? And the comparison is similar to what I added here too.

> @jipanyang can you point me to an example? I need to get the problem under control first. Can we move on then improve?

View switch design and implementation:
https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/blob/master/doc/warm-reboot/view_switch.md
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss-common/pull/247

Usage example:
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/725

We found view switch mechanism is able to handle FV vectors with non-ordered and variable number of fields.  
Not sure about 210811 branch, but for master branch I think we should move to view switch mechanism.
@vsenchyshyn add a comment "retest this please" can trigger a new build and test chain. We do not need to create a new pr

> @vsenchyshyn add a comment "retest this please" can trigger a new build and test chain. We do not need to create a new pr

Wow interesting trick! Thanks a bunch!

Also you do not need to create a separate pr specifically for 20181130 image. There is a label in the label section called "request in 20181130 image".  Just add it to your original pr to mark the necessity for 1130 inclusive. Maintainer will pick it up later once it is merged to master

> could you correct the commit title name to orchagent?

Done!
Please add this to the 201811 branch as well as master

Hi @prsunny, I have another question about the return value in `addOperation` . e.g. VxlanTunnelMapOrch::addOperation, it returns false means the request will not be erased from the queue and retry in next time. Does the retry mechanism have retry count limit? or it always retry?   Thanks

> Hi @prsunny, I have another question about the return value in addOperation . e.g. VxlanTunnelMapOrch::addOperation, it returns false means the request will not be erased from the queue and retry in next time. Does the retry mechanism have retry count limit? or it always retry?   Thanks

It always retry. That's why some cases, we intentionally return `true `so as to erase from Queue
Thanks for explaining, @prsunny. I’m wondering if the request is always retried, has it the possibility to cause queue full? If yes, how to process this case.

Potentially a queue full can happen if all the request are failing. I think it would be abnormal to have a que full of requests that's failing. Mostly we observed some requests fails and it keeps retrying but other requests coming will be processed and freed from queue.

I am now more leaning towards the DB solution. This change only solves the problem as long as orchagent_restart_check didn't quit. But DB solution can support even if we retry warm-reboot.

And BTW, orchagent_restart_check  should be renamed to something like pause_orchagent

> I am now more leaning towards the DB solution. This change only solves the problem as long as orchagent_restart_check didn't quit. But DB solution can support even if we retry warm-reboot.
> 
> And BTW, orchagent_restart_check should be renamed to something like pause_orchagent

I'm not sure if I get it, for warm-reboot retry,  orchagent_restart_check will be started again.  If there is no reply in 10 ~12 seconds for 6 RESTARTCHECK signal,  the system should be in wrong state, no further warm restart should be tried. 

Below is a snippet of docker warm upgrade code we use, jut fyi.   
```
            cmd = "docker exec -i swss orchagent_restart_check -w 2000 -r 5 " + skipPendingTaskCheck

            proc = subprocess.Popen(cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, shell=True)
            (out, err) = proc.communicate()
            if proc.returncode != 0:
                if not skip_check:
                    click.echo("Orchagent is not in clean state, RESTARTCHECK failed")
                    # Restore orignal config before exit
                    if warm_configured == False and warm:
                        run_command("config warm_restart disable %s" % container_name)
                    sys.exit(proc.returncode)
                else:
                    click.echo("Orchagent is not in clean state, upgrading it anyway")
            else:
                click.echo("Orchagent is in clean state and frozen for warm upgrade")
```

But please go ahead with the DB solution implementation. I don't see any major issue with that approach either.

This might be an extreme example, but what if the orchagent takes 12 second to complete pausing? Most of the time were spent draining the queue? restart_check gave up after 10 seconds, and then you have a paused orchagent and unable to warm-reboot?

> This might be an extreme example, but what if the orchagent takes 12 second to complete pausing? Most of the time were spent draining the queue? restart_check gave up after 10 seconds, and then you have a paused orchagent and unable to warm-reboot?

With DB solution,  the same issue needs to be handled as well.  If orchagent has been in paused state for too long before another warm reboot retry, the state of whole system is messed up likely.  In that case you might want a clean cold upgrade.

Got some time to think about the problem a little bit more, actually just before orchagent pauses itself, a "paused" state could be set to warm_restart_table:  https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/blob/master/doc/swss-schema.md#warm_restart_table

This way orchagent_restart_check problem may check the flag before trying to send out RESTARTCHECK siginal to orchagent, if it is already in paused state, just clear the state and return success(?). 

This also gives more visibility of orchagent state,

Currently we check pending task state of orchagent, there might be more states to check for processes in  swss container.
@jipanyang  please make the matching sonic-utilities change.
Has it passed the pfc watchdog test?

> We are calling SAI API to configure serdes tuning values thru orchagent, why not thru syncd?
> How we determine thru which entity to access asic? Do we have a general guidance?

Hi @stevenlu99 , The API called in orchagent actually calls the libsairedis API. This will write into ASIC_DB and which in turn messages the syncd. Syncd then deserializes the parameters and invokes the vendor specific SAI API that programs the NPU.
This is the general design followed in all the SAI calls and i followed the same here too.
